text: The currency of politics is attention, not money.

claim.text: The currency of politics is attention, not money.

nodes.text: The main claim that attention is more important than money in politics.
nodes.label: The currency of politics is attention, not money
nodes.reason: While attention is certainly important in politics, independent research indicates that a significant majority of Americans support limits on money in politics, suggesting money also plays a critical role and cannot be easily dismissed.

research.title: 7 facts about Americans' views of money in politics
research.summary: This Pew Research Center article reports on Americans' views of money in politics, based on a July 2023 survey of 8,480 adults.  The article does *not* claim that attention is more important than money; rather, it highlights widespread dissatisfaction with the influence of money in politics.  Key findings include large numbers of people believing political campaigns are too expensive, elected officials are too responsive to donors, and members of Congress cannot or will not separate their financial interests from their public duties.  The article presents data showing that about 7 in 10 U.S. adults believe there should be limits on election spending.
highlights: Just 11% say individuals and organizations should be able to spend as much money as they want, and 16% are not sure. [! Liberal Democrats are particularly likely to say it’s possible to have laws that would reduce the role of money in politics. About three-quarters (76%) say this, compared with 57% of conservative or moderate Democrats and 52% of Republicans. There are no ideological differences on this question among Republicans.

research.title: 5. Money, power and the influence of ordinary people in American ...
research.summary: This Pew Research Center report doesn't support the claim that attention is more important than money in politics.  Instead, it highlights the widespread belief among Americans that large political donors and special interests exert excessive influence on political decisions, while ordinary citizens have too little influence.  The report emphasizes the common perception that money plays a significant role in who runs for office and the decisions made by members of Congress, with major donors and lobbyists seen as having far more influence than constituents.
highlights: [Chart shows most favor limits on spending in elections, say it would be possible to reduce role of money in politics](https://www.pewresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/20/2023/09/PP_2023.09.19_views-of-politics_05-03.png)](https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2023/09/19/money-power-and-the-influence-of-ordinary-people-in-american-politics/pp_2023-09-19_views-of-politics_05-03-png/) Democrats are more likely than Republicans to say it is possible to have laws that reduce the influence of money on politics. About two-thirds of Democrats say this is possible (66%), while only 16% say it is not. Roughly half of Republicans (52%) think this is possible, while 29% say it is not. [!

research.title: Money in Politics | International IDEA
research.summary: The provided text does not support the claim that attention is more important than money in politics.  Instead, it emphasizes that while money is necessary for political participation,  lack of effective regulation of political finance and lobbying can undermine democratic integrity, transparency, and accountability.  The International IDEA's work focuses on improving these areas through research, technical assistance, and policy advocacy.
highlights: Money is a necessary component of any democracy: it enables political participation and representation. However, if not effectively regulated, it can undermine the integrity of political processes and institutions and jeopardize the quality of democracy. Regulations related to the funding of political parties and election campaigns (commonly known as political finance) and lobbying are critical to promote integrity, transparency and accountability in any democracy. For the last 20 years, International IDEA has been contributing to the discussion about Money in Politics by analyzing trends, producing comparative data and research, providing technical assistance to oversight agencies and political parties, and convening policy platforms for peer-to-peer learning among the leading practitioners. Our work aims to improve the level of transparency and accountability in political processes and institutions worldwide.

nodes.text: Subclaim that attention is a necessary resource for political success.
nodes.label: Attention is a necessary resource in politics
nodes.reason: While there is support for the idea that attention plays a significant role in political communication and strategy, the research also indicates that merely attracting attention does not guarantee political success and can even be counterproductive.

research.title: A Possible Framework for Attention-Based Politics: A Field for Research
research.summary: This 2019 article by Norbert Merkovity proposes a framework for understanding "attention-based politics," arguing that in the social media age, politicians engage in "self-broadcasting" to attract and manage the attention of followers and journalists.  The author suggests that the ability to capture and direct attention is a crucial resource for political success, moving beyond traditional notions of mediatization and spin doctoring.  The article outlines this framework and proposes further research into the strategies politicians employ to achieve this.
highlights: According to scholars, the use of mediatization could be understood as a communicative representation of politicians or spin doctoring, but either way, it ends in self-representation and in “self-initiated stage-management.” However, the social media environment could give a new perspective on the communication of the political actors in political communication. This communication could be seen as self-broadcasting that could be conceptualized as attention-based politics. This article aims to give a brief introduction to a theoretical framework of the phenomenon and to provide research directions in order to understand politician's strategies in attraction, maximization, and the direction the attention of followers and journalists.

research.title: The attention economy is devouring politics
research.summary: The author counters the argument that attention isn't crucial for political success, presented by John Sides in *Good Authority*.  While acknowledging that attracting attention might not guarantee votes and could even alienate some, the author argues that political science needs to better understand the dynamics of attention, technology, and bandwidth in shaping political outcomes.  Current political science methods, relying heavily on static surveys, fail to capture the complexities of attention flows, a point highlighted by Chris Hayes's book, *The Siren's Call*.
highlights: Even if Trump and other Republicans are good at getting eyeballs, they may not win enough votes, and might even alienate people. Attracting attention may end up being a bad idea. _Good Authority_ is a political science publication\* and John was making a case for the established wisdoms of political science. It was a good case, and one which, I am pretty sure that Chris would largely agree with (he says some pretty similar things in the book). But in the interests of good argument, I’d like to keep the dialectic going, counter-claiming that standard political science could greatly benefit from engaging with the ideas that Chris and Ezra batted around in their conversation, and that are discussed in greater depth in Chris’s book.

nodes.text: Subclaim that money is less important than attention in politics.
nodes.label: Money is a less important resource than attention in politics
nodes.reason: While some research indicates that attention can serve as a significant currency in politics, it does not conclusively prove that it is more important than money, as the efficacy of attention in garnering votes is still debated among political scientists.

research.title: The attention economy is devouring politics
research.summary: This article argues that the current focus in political science on traditional metrics like surveys overlooks the crucial role of "attention" in modern politics.  While acknowledging that attracting attention doesn't guarantee electoral success, the author counters the view that attention is unimportant.  The piece suggests that political scientists should incorporate the dynamics of attention, technology, and information flow into their analyses, arguing that a focus on attention may offer a more accurate understanding of political power than traditional methods.  The author implicitly supports the subclaim that attention is at least as important as money, by highlighting the limitations of traditional political science which predominantly focuses on factors other than attention.
highlights: Even if Trump and other Republicans are good at getting eyeballs, they may not win enough votes, and might even alienate people. Attracting attention may end up being a bad idea. _Good Authority_ is a political science publication\* and John was making a case for the established wisdoms of political science. It was a good case, and one which, I am pretty sure that Chris would largely agree with (he says some pretty similar things in the book). But in the interests of good argument, I’d like to keep the dialectic going, counter-claiming that standard political science could greatly benefit from engaging with the ideas that Chris and Ezra batted around in their conversation, and that are discussed in greater depth in Chris’s book.

research.title: Attention: The Universal Currency - Societal Engineering - Medium
research.summary: This article discusses the nature of money, outlining its functions as a store of value, unit of account, and medium of exchange.  It does *not* contain a subclaim arguing that attention is more important than money in politics.  The article focuses on the historical and economic aspects of currency, not political power dynamics.
highlights: But the point that I want to stress here is not just that attention _leads to_ money. I am saying that attention is a form of currency all by itself. It can be gathered, through hard work, luck, or both, and then “traded” for the other things that a person needs. In a way, it is a more raw form of money than actual cash, as it is desired at a more intrinsic level than the paper dollar. Check out my personal development book, [Ideal Attainment: How to Reprogram the Mind and Undo Your Faulty Conditioning](https://www.amazon.com/Ideal-Attainment-Reprogram-Faulty-Conditioning-ebook/dp/B071CHZ2GY/ref=sr_1_1?keywords=jesse+dvorak&qid=1560165890&s=gateway&sr=8-1).

nodes.text: Subclaim that politicians need attention to get elected.
nodes.label: Politicians need attention to get elected
nodes.reason: Independent research supports the claim that politicians need attention to secure electoral success, highlighting the importance of personal interactions and media coverage in influencing voter behavior.

research.title: What’s the number one priority for politicians, more than anything else? Getting elected.
research.summary: The author argues that getting elected (or re-elected) is the top priority for most politicians, sometimes even outweighing good policy.  While acknowledging some idealistic politicians might prioritize good policy, the author contends that the need for attention and votes often drives political decisions.  This is supported by anecdotes from the author's conversations with politicians and observations of their behavior.
highlights: If it appeals to their supporters, they won’t care unless they’re in a marginal seat, and especially if there’s the prospect of losing votes.

research.title: Politicians in the Media: Determinants of Legislators' Presence and Prominence in Swiss Newspapers
research.summary: This study of Swiss newspaper coverage of politicians finds that those in leadership positions receive the most media attention.  While parliamentary activity also increases media coverage, the research does not strongly support the idea that media bias significantly influences which politicians are featured.  This suggests that, while not explicitly stating it, the research implicitly supports the notion that achieving prominence (and thus potentially, election) requires securing media attention, particularly through holding leadership roles.
highlights: Third, theories of “news bias” hold that the media privilege legislators who are in line with their own editorial interests. Overall, the statistical analyses show an important leadership effect and provide strong support for the second explanation. While deputies in official functions get the most extensive news coverage, media access can also be won by parliamentary activity. The least support is shown for the news bias theory, although some newspapers try to localize parliamentary news coverage by focusing on deputies from their own media market.

research.title: Personal Attention in Politics
research.summary: This article, "Personal Attention in Politics," by John T. Salter (University of Wisconsin), published in the *American Political Science Review* in September 2013, does not explicitly state that politicians *need* attention to get elected as a central claim.  The provided text is limited to metadata and navigational links; it offers no insight into the article's actual content or arguments.  To determine if the article supports this subclaim, accessing the full text of the article is necessary.
highlights: There is a lag, when the man with a smile, or handclasp, a warm greeting, or a personal favor, will win. Notwithstanding what may be the voter's attitude in the future, today he is apt to be interested in the candidate who pays him personal attention or does him a personal favor. What the voter does is not necessarily determined by logic; for life is not logical. 2 See my sketches of ward politicians in _Boss Rule; Portraits in City Politics_. The statement of one of the leaders is descriptive of many.

nodes.text: Subclaim that political movements need attention to gain traction.
nodes.label: Political movements need attention to gain traction
nodes.reason: Independent research supports that political movements require visibility and engagement with the public to gain traction, as evidenced by scholarly work on strategies and organizational forms essential for mobilization and influence.

research.title: How Social Movements Matter
research.summary: The book "How Social Movements Matter," edited by Giugni, McAdam, and Tilly, implicitly supports the subclaim that political movements require attention to gain traction.  While the provided text doesn't explicitly state this, the very title and the series' focus on "Social Movements, Protest, and Contention" suggest that the book explores how these movements gain influence and achieve their goals, which inherently necessitates a degree of public awareness and engagement—i.e., attention.
highlights: Volume 4 Hank Johnston and Bert Klandermans, eds., Social Movements Volume 3 J. Craig Jenkins and Bert Klandermans, eds., The Politics of Social Protest: Comparative Perspectives on States and Social Volume 2 John Foran, ed., A Century of Revolution: Social Movements Volume 1 Andrew Szasz, EcoPopulism: Toxic Waste and the Movement

research.title: The Political Consequences of Social Movements
research.summary: This article review on the political consequences of social movements notes that while many studies show the influence of large movements,  research hasn't definitively established *how much* they matter.  Initial hypotheses suggesting that mobilization strategies, organizational forms, and political contexts directly translate to political influence are being revised.  The review emphasizes the need for further research exploring the complex interactions between movement characteristics, actions, and diverse political contexts to better understand when and how movements gain influence.  The article doesn't directly support the subclaim that movements *need* attention to gain traction, but it highlights the ongoing debate and lack of conclusive evidence on the factors contributing to a movement's success.
highlights: As for the conditions under which movements matter, scholars have been revising their initial hypotheses that the strategies, organizational forms, and political contexts that aid mobilization also aid in gaining and exerting political influence. Scholars are exploring alternative arguments about the productivity of different actions and characteristics of movements and movement organizations in the varied political contexts and institutional settings they face. Researchers are also employing more innovative research designs to appraise these more complex arguments. Scholarship will advance best if scholars continue to think through the interactions between strategies, organizations, and contexts; address movement influences on processes in institutional politics beyond the agenda-setting stage; situate case studies in comparative and historical perspective; and make more comparisons across movements and issues.   /content/journals/10.1146/annurev-soc-070308-120029

research.title: From social movements to political movements
research.summary: The provided text doesn't directly support the subclaim that political movements need attention to gain traction.  While the article analyzes the formation and development of social movements and their transformation into political movements, examining factors like strategy, organization, and comparing examples from Denmark, Germany, and Great Britain, it does not explicitly state or imply that attention is a necessary condition for a political movement's success.
highlights: Il se demande comment ceux-ci deviennent des mouvements politiques. Il examine la theorie des nouveaux mouvements sociaux et s'efforce de comprendre le role des facteurs sociaux et des facteurs politiques. Il decrit les differents types de strategie politique et d'organisation des mouvements politiques. Il analyse les principaux mouvements de masse qui ont marque la vie politique danoise entre 1973 et 198, puis compare la situation et l'organisation des mouvements de masse au Danemark, en Allemagne et en Grande-Bretagne

nodes.text: Subclaim that low-budget campaigns can still be successful.
nodes.label: Political campaigns with less money can still be successful
nodes.reason: Independent research provides multiple examples, including a successful $50 campaign and a college election win on a $200 budget, demonstrating that low-budget campaigns can produce effective results.

research.title: I Built A Marketing Campaign With Just $50. The Results Shocked Me.
research.summary: The author of this article challenged the notion that marketing requires a large budget by creating a successful marketing campaign with only $50.  They aimed to prove that effective marketing relies more on strategy than expensive resources.  The article details this campaign and its unexpectedly positive results, demonstrating the viability of low-budget marketing.

research.title: How to Run a Marketing Campaign on a Tight Budget [Expert Tips & Free Tools]
research.summary: Even with limited budgets, successful marketing campaigns are achievable.  Experts advise focusing on targeted advertising (Facebook Ads, Google AdWords) to maximize reach, leveraging free promotional channels like social media and email marketing, and proactively pitching to the press for free publicity.  Realistic expectations and a clear value proposition are crucial for success.  Collaboration with internal teams is also key.
highlights: You can play around with both tools.

research.title: How This College Kid Won A Local Election On A $200 Budget
research.summary: Lee Jackson, a 19-year-old University of Maine student, won a local school board election on a budget of only $200.  He achieved this through extensive door-knocking, coalition building, community organizing, and engaging in local events, proving that a successful campaign doesn't require significant funding.  While acknowledging that money plays a role in larger campaigns, Jackson's victory demonstrates that grassroots efforts and strong community connections can outweigh financial resources.
highlights: At the ripe age of 19, Jackson [was elected](http://mainecampus.com/2013/11/10/umaine-student-lee-jackson-elected-to-old-town-school-board/) to the Regional School District No. 34 School Board in Old Town, Maine, all while maintaining his grades and working a part-time job at McDonald's.

nodes.text: Subclaim that high-budget campaigns can still fail.
nodes.label: Political campaigns with more money can still fail
nodes.reason: Independent research shows that even high-budget campaigns can fail due to factors like ineffective audience targeting and overspending without proper strategy, supporting the claim that high-budget campaigns can still be unsuccessful.

research.title: 7 Reasons Google Ads Isn't Reaching Your Full Daily Budget
research.summary: Even with a high daily budget set in Google Ads, campaigns can underspend if bids are too low, ad rank is poor, keywords have low search volume, insufficient keywords are used, click-through rates are low, targeting is too narrow, or the ad schedule is too short.  These factors limit ad impressions and thus, spending.
highlights: This will use more of your budget, and you might find some new higher-value keywords in the process! I have a video campaign that was running with three ad creatives. After they ran for a week or two, we decided to split the creatives into separate campaigns to spread the budget evenly between videos. So the new campaigns are simply duplicates of the original campaign, but for some reason they're now only spending a fraction of the budget. The only exclusions are a handful of placements.

research.title: Why Facebook Ads Fail: The Missing Brand Awareness Strategies
research.summary: The article claims that even with advanced strategies, Facebook ad campaigns can fail due to a lack of brand awareness.  The author argues that focusing solely on bottom-of-the-funnel metrics neglects the crucial top-of-funnel work needed to build brand recognition, which is essential for conversions.  Therefore, high-budget campaigns may still fail if they don't incorporate effective brand awareness strategies.
highlights: If that sounds high, remember that larger audiences result in lower costs-per-thousand impressions (CPMs). In the beginning, you’ll need to keep adding interests and brand names to build up that list over the recommended 2 million person threshold. But once your list size peaks at or over 10 million, you’ll want to start reducing the number to the ideal size by adding audience exclusions. Make sense? Now: Let’s go back to our example from a few minutes ago.

research.title: Why You're Overspending On Meta Ads - Digital Position
research.summary: While Meta's ad algorithm can lead to overspending, particularly on smaller budgets (e.g., a $10/day budget exceeding its limit by $7.50 is more likely than a $10,000/day budget exceeding it by a similar percentage),  the article doesn't directly support the subclaim that high-budget campaigns can still fail *due to overspending*.  It focuses on the algorithm's flexibility and potential for exceeding daily budgets, but doesn't discuss campaign failure specifically.
highlights: That’s entirely within the realm of possibility, and it can add up over time if you’re not keeping tabs on it.   If you’re looking for a backup plan to completely avoid overspending in your Meta Ads account, you can set up rules to automate the process.
